scenarios.name: Non-IID Label Skew (Heterogeneity)
scenarios.description: Evaluate convergence stability when clients have highly skewed label distributions, stressing client drift.
scenarios.dataset: Synthetic logistic regression with client partitions constructed so each client predominantly observes a single class (e.g., ~80% of one label) and mild feature shift across subsets.
scenarios.expected_insight: SFedAvg’s projected momentum should reduce client drift and yield smoother, faster convergence than FedAvg under non-IID label skew; FedAvg may exhibit oscillations and slower accuracy gains.

scenarios.name: Robustness to Noise and Outliers
scenarios.description: Test sensitivity to corrupted supervision and feature outliers.
scenarios.dataset: Increase label noise to ~30% via random flips and inject ~5% heavy-tailed feature outliers per client; maintain unequal noise levels across clients.
scenarios.expected_insight: Projected momentum in SFedAvg should dampen the influence of corrupted gradients, preserving test accuracy better than FedAvg; FedAvg may overfit noisy patterns and suffer accuracy drops.

scenarios.name: Scalability: High-Dimensional, Large-Scale
scenarios.description: Assess convergence and communication behavior as data size and model dimension scale up.
scenarios.dataset: Large synthetic logistic dataset with balanced labels; clients receive equal-sized random partitions to focus on scale effects.
scenarios.expected_insight: FedAvg should be more communication-efficient, while SFedAvg may achieve comparable or faster convergence in rounds but incur significantly higher communication (due to Pi of size d×d); highlights the trade-off.

scenarios.name: Hyperparameter Sensitivity: Momentum and Subspace
scenarios.description: Probe sensitivity to momentum (μ) and subspace dimension (r).
scenarios.dataset: Balanced synthetic logistic data; repeat runs while sweeping μ ∈ {0.0, 0.5, 0.9} and r ∈ {8, 16, 32} to map stability and speed.
scenarios.expected_insight: There should be a sweet spot for μ and r where SFedAvg accelerates without instability; too-small r can underfit important directions, too-large r can behave like full momentum and be less robust.

scenarios.name: Edge Case: Few Clients Selected, Many Local Steps
scenarios.description: Stress-test failure modes with tiny client fraction and heavy local computation.
scenarios.dataset: Balanced data but select very few clients per round; enforce long local updates to amplify drift with minimal aggregation.
scenarios.expected_insight: FedAvg may overfit local client trajectories and diverge; SFedAvg with r=1 and high μ can stall or oscillate, revealing sensitivity to extreme projection and momentum.

scenario_design.rationale: These scenarios directly stress elements in the pseudocode: round-wise projected momentum (Π_t g) and subspace dimension r, client sampling, and aggregation. Together they test non-IID heterogeneity, robustness to corrupted gradients, scaling trade-offs between convergence and communication, sensitivity to μ and r, and edge cases that expose stability limits.

tuning_strategy.selection_rationale: In high-dimensional, large-scale federated settings, increasing client_fraction reduces gradient variance and speeds per-round convergence but raises communication; stepsize governs stability and progress per update, where high dimensionality can make large steps unstable; local_steps trades local computation vs aggregation frequency, controlling drift and rounds needed. Together these parameters shape both convergence speed and communication cost.

configs.rationale: More clients per round to reduce variance and accelerate convergence without changing optimization dynamics; expect fewer rounds to target loss at higher communication per round.
Increase aggregation frequency (shorter local training) to curb drift; moderate increase in clients to speed convergence while keeping LR stable.
Maintain baseline client count, use slightly higher LR with shorter local training to boost progress per round while mitigating instability.
Aggressive communication reduction via fewer clients; compensate with more local steps and smaller LR to preserve stability; tests comm–convergence trade-off.
High aggregation with slightly smaller LR to avoid overshooting in high dimension; target fast rounds-to-acc with controlled stability.
Increase local computation with smaller LR to reduce rounds while monitoring drift; evaluates whether longer local training helps in large scale.
Stress higher LR for faster progress under baseline aggregation; checks stability limits in high dimension.
Balanced setting: more clients and shorter local steps with slightly higher LR for faster, stable convergence and improved comm per target accuracy.

tuning_strategy.expected_improvement: Compared to baseline, configurations with higher client_fraction (0.2–0.3) and/or shorter local_steps (2) should cut rounds to target loss by ~15–30% and improve test accuracy early, while settings with tuned stepsize (0.06–0.10) should maintain stability. Overall, FedAvg should reach 0.8 accuracy in fewer rounds and lower total communication to target; SFedAvg should see smoother loss and modest accuracy gains but remains communication-heavy per round.

config.rationale: More clients per round to reduce variance and accelerate convergence without changing optimization dynamics; expect fewer rounds to target loss at higher communication per round.
Increase aggregation frequency (shorter local training) to curb drift; moderate increase in clients to speed convergence while keeping LR stable.
Maintain baseline client count, use slightly higher LR with shorter local training to boost progress per round while mitigating instability.
Aggressive communication reduction via fewer clients; compensate with more local steps and smaller LR to preserve stability; tests comm–convergence trade-off.
High aggregation with slightly smaller LR to avoid overshooting in high dimension; target fast rounds-to-acc with controlled stability.
Increase local computation with smaller LR to reduce rounds while monitoring drift; evaluates whether longer local training helps in large scale.
Stress higher LR for faster progress under baseline aggregation; checks stability limits in high dimension.
Balanced setting: more clients and shorter local steps with slightly higher LR for faster, stable convergence and improved comm per target accuracy.

analysis.analysis:
tuning/scalability_high_dim_large_scale_analysis.txt
```python
<<<<<<< SEARCH
=======
Best Configuration:
- Config 7: client_fraction=0.1, stepsize=0.12, local_steps=3. This setting achieved the fastest convergence (rounds_to_target_loss_fedavg=8) while reducing communication to reach 0.8 accuracy (comm_per_0.8_acc_fedavg=80,400) versus baseline.

Performance Improvement:
- Compared to baseline, rounds to target loss improved from 12 to 8 (33.3% fewer rounds), and communication to reach 0.8 accuracy dropped from 128,640 to 80,400 (37.5% reduction). Overall test accuracy ramped faster across rounds with higher LR while remaining stable.

Parameter Insights:
- Stepsize had the strongest impact: increasing eta to 0.12 markedly accelerated convergence without instability in this high-dimensional regime. Client_fraction controlled the communication trade-off; lower C (e.g., 0.05) drastically cut comm with modest impact on rounds. Local_steps showed a sweet spot near 3; too few steps (2) with moderate C underperformed, while too many steps (5) improved rounds but often raised comm to hit target accuracy.

Recommendation:
- Use client_fraction=0.1, stepsize=0.12, local_steps=3 for best overall speed–communication trade-off in this scenario. If communication budget is extremely tight, prefer client_fraction=0.05, stepsize=0.07, local_steps=4 to minimize comm per 0.8 accuracy (−59.4% vs baseline) with only a slight rounds increase vs the best.
```

execution_results.name: hyperparameter_sensitivity:_momentum_and_subspace
execution_results.description: Probe sensitivity to momentum (μ) and subspace dimension (r).
execution_results.dataset: Balanced synthetic logistic data; repeat runs while sweeping μ ∈ {0.0, 0.5, 0.9} and r ∈ {8, 16, 32} to map stability and speed.
execution_results.expected_insight: There should be a sweet spot for μ and r where SFedAvg accelerates without instability; too-small r can underfit important directions, too-large r can behave like full momentum and be less robust.
execution_results.implementation_note: Code was customized for this scenario's specific requirements

tuning_strategy.selection_rationale: In this scenario, SFedAvg’s behavior is primarily governed by momentum (μ), which controls accumulation and smoothing of projected gradients, and subspace dimension (r), which determines how much of the gradient space is retained by the projection. Stepsize (η) directly scales update magnitude and interacts with μ and r to balance speed vs stability. Tuning these three jointly targets faster convergence without inducing oscillations, while keeping other parameters at their defaults.

configs.rationale: Balanced smoothing with expanded subspace; slight LR reduction to curb overshoot while increasing useful directions.
High μ with moderate r to accelerate; keep baseline LR to test speed gains versus stability.
Lower μ at baseline r to reduce oscillations; smaller LR to stabilize while retaining reasonable pace.
Large r approximates full directions; reduce μ and LR to mitigate instability and explore faster convergence safely.
Strong momentum with modestly larger r; slightly lower LR to prevent over-accumulation while aiming for faster rounds.
Wide subspace with strong (not extreme) momentum; conservative LR to harness speed without oscillations.
No-momentum control with larger r to isolate projection effects on stability and speed.

tuning_strategy.expected_improvement: Relative to baseline (μ=0.9, r=8, η=0.12), these settings should reduce rounds_to_target_loss_sfedavg by ~20–40%, increase mid-round test_acc_sfedavg by ~1–3%, and lower comm_per_0.8_acc_sfedavg proportionally by reaching the target accuracy earlier.

config.rationale: Balanced smoothing with expanded subspace; slight LR reduction to curb overshoot while increasing useful directions.
High μ with moderate r to accelerate; keep baseline LR to test speed gains versus stability.
Lower μ at baseline r to reduce oscillations; smaller LR to stabilize while retaining reasonable pace.
Large r approximates full directions; reduce μ and LR to mitigate instability and explore faster convergence safely.
Strong momentum with modestly larger r; slightly lower LR to prevent over-accumulation while aiming for faster rounds.
Wide subspace with strong (not extreme) momentum; conservative LR to harness speed without oscillations.
No-momentum control with larger r to isolate projection effects on stability and speed.

analysis.analysis:
tuning/hyperparameter_sensitivity_momentum_and_subspace_analysis.txt
```text
<<<<<<< SEARCH
=======
Best Configuration:
The top-performing SFedAvg setting is momentum=0.8, subspace_dim=32, stepsize=0.08 (config 6). It achieved rounds_to_target_loss_sfedavg=8 and comm_per_0.8_acc_sfedavg=1,144,330—both the best among all tested configurations. Its area_under_accuracy_curve_sfedavg reached 32.675, indicating a faster accuracy ramp than baseline. The stability_index_sfedavg was lower (~71.5), reflecting a speed–stability trade-off.

Performance Improvement:
Compared to baseline (μ=0.9, r=8, η=0.12), config 6 reduced rounds_to_target_loss_sfedavg from 24 to 8 (−66.7%). Communication to reach 0.8 accuracy dropped from 3,432,990 to 1,144,330 (−66.7%). Area under the accuracy curve improved by ~17.3%. Stability_index decreased by ~55%, indicating increased volatility with the faster convergence.

Parameter Insights:
Subspace dimension r was the strongest lever; increasing r to 32 unlocked faster convergence and large communication savings when paired with appropriate stepsize. Stepsize interacted critically with r and μ; reducing η to 0.08 stabilized the higher-dimensional projection and enabled aggressive acceleration without obvious divergence. Momentum controlled the speed–stability balance: moderate–high μ (0.8–0.9) accelerated but increased volatility, while μ=0.0 improved stability at the cost of much slower convergence and higher communication to reach 0.8 accuracy.

Recommendation:
Use SFedAvg with momentum=0.8, subspace_dim=32, stepsize=0.08 for this scenario to maximize speed and communication efficiency. If stability is the priority, prefer momentum=0.7, subspace_dim=8, stepsize=0.1 (config 3) or consider momentum=0.5, subspace_dim=32, stepsize=0.1 (config 4) for a balanced alternative. Keep other parameters at scenario defaults and monitor stability_index to ensure acceptable volatility for deployment.
>>>>>>> REPLACE
```
